lines.text: Enter DUKE and THURIO

lines.speaker: duke
lines.text: Sir Thurio, fear not but that she will love you, Now Valentine is banishd from her sight.

lines.speaker: thurio
lines.text: Since his exile she hath despised me most, Forsworn my company and raild at me, That I am desperate of obtaining her.

lines.speaker: duke
lines.text: This weak impress of love is as a figure Trenched in ice, which with an hours heat Dissolves to water and doth lose his form. A little time will melt her frozen thoughts And worthless Valentine shall be forgot. How now, Sir Proteus! Is your countryman According to our proclamation gone
Enter PROTEUS

lines.speaker: proteus
lines.text: Gone, my good lord.

lines.speaker: duke
lines.text: My daughter takes his going grievously.

lines.speaker: proteus
lines.text: A little time, my lord, will kill that grief.

lines.speaker: duke
lines.text: So I believe but Thurio thinks not so. Proteus, the good conceit I hold of thee For thou hast shown some sign of good desert Makes me the better to confer with thee.

lines.speaker: proteus
lines.text: Longer than I prove loyal to your grace Let me not live to look upon your grace.

lines.speaker: duke
lines.text: Thou knowst how willingly I would effect The match between Sir Thurio and my daughter.

lines.speaker: proteus
lines.text: I do, my lord.

lines.speaker: duke
lines.text: And also, I think, thou art not ignorant How she opposes her against my will

lines.speaker: proteus
lines.text: She did, my lord, when Valentine was here.

lines.speaker: duke
lines.text: Ay, and perversely she persevers so. What might we do to make the girl forget The love of Valentine and love Sir Thurio

lines.speaker: proteus
lines.text: The best way is to slander Valentine With falsehood, cowardice and poor descent, Three things that women highly hold in hate.

lines.speaker: duke
lines.text: Ay, but shell think that it is spoke in hate.

lines.speaker: proteus
lines.text: Ay, if his enemy deliver it: Therefore it must with circumstance be spoken By one whom she esteemeth as his friend.

lines.speaker: duke
lines.text: Then you must undertake to slander him.

lines.speaker: proteus
lines.text: And that, my lord, I shall be loath to do: Tis an ill office for a gentleman, Especially against his very friend.

lines.speaker: duke
lines.text: Where your good word cannot advantage him, Your slander never can endamage him Therefore the office is indifferent, Being entreated to it by your friend.

lines.speaker: proteus
lines.text: You have prevaild, my lord if I can do it By ought that I can speak in his dispraise, She shall not long continue love to him. But say this weed her love from Valentine, It follows not that she will love Sir Thurio.

lines.speaker: thurio
lines.text: Therefore, as you unwind her love from him, Lest it should ravel and be good to none, You must provide to bottom it on me Which must be done by praising me as much As you in worth dispraise Sir Valentine.

lines.speaker: duke
lines.text: And, Proteus, we dare trust you in this kind, Because we know, on Valentines report, You are already Loves firm votary And cannot soon revolt and change your mind. Upon this warrant shall you have access Where you with Silvia may confer at large For she is lumpish, heavy, melancholy, And, for your friends sake, will be glad of you Where you may temper her by your persuasion To hate young Valentine and love my friend.

lines.speaker: proteus
lines.text: As much as I can do, I will effect: But you, Sir Thurio, are not sharp enough You must lay lime to tangle her desires By wailful sonnets, whose composed rhymes Should be fullfraught with serviceable vows.

lines.speaker: duke
lines.text: Ay, Much is the force of heavenbred poesy.

lines.speaker: proteus
lines.text: Say that upon the altar of her beauty You sacrifice your tears, your sighs, your heart: Write till your ink be dry, and with your tears Moist it again, and frame some feeling line That may discover such integrity: For Orpheus lute was strung with poets sinews, Whose golden touch could soften steel and stones, Make tigers tame and huge leviathans Forsake unsounded deeps to dance on sands. After your direlamenting elegies, Visit by night your ladys chamberwindow With some sweet concert to their instruments Tune a deploring dump: the nights dead silence Will well become such sweetcomplaining grievance. This, or else nothing, will inherit her.

lines.speaker: duke
lines.text: This discipline shows thou hast been in love.

lines.speaker: thurio
lines.text: And thy advice this night Ill put in practise. Therefore, sweet Proteus, my directiongiver, Let us into the city presently To sort some gentlemen well skilld in music. I have a sonnet that will serve the turn To give the onset to thy good advice.

lines.speaker: duke
lines.text: About it, gentlemen!

lines.speaker: proteus
lines.text: Well wait upon your grace till after supper, And afterward determine our proceedings.

lines.speaker: duke
lines.text: Even now about it! I will pardon you.
Exeunt
